name: lely-kiosk
readme:
# LELY-kiosk

This project consists of three main programs and a number of development tools

net.lustlab.lely.KioskServer is the main server program used for pantries, restaurant and entrance kiosks
net.lustlab.lely.KioskClient is the client program user for pantries, restaurant and entrance kiosks
net.lustlab.lely.MeetingroomKiosk is the program used for meeting room kiosks

net.lustlab.lely.WidgetTester is a development tool in which a single widget can be tested

## Getting things to run

 * Run net.lustlab.lely.KioskServer with arguments config/schedule-<target>.yaml
 * Run net.lustlab.lely.KioskClient on the hosts targetted in the config file

## Developing and testing a single widget

 * copy config/widgettester.template.yaml to config/widgettester.yaml
 * edit config/widgettester.yaml
 * run net.lustlab.lely.WidgetTester

name: Lely API
readme:
# Install notes Lely API for development

- Make a new database
- Install tables: /db/tables.sql
- Install data: /db/datatypes.sql
- Check for DB updates and run them. /db/updates
- Verify database credentials in /vendor/Lely/DataBaseConnection.php
- Install Memcached with homebrew: brew install memcached

For the _/lely/videos_ and _/lely/posters_ routes, the Lely API VirtualHost configuration in Apache needs 2 aliases to serve the videos and posters. On the server this looks like this:

    Alias /assets/videos /home/lust/www/assets/videos
    Alias /assets/posters /home/lust/www/assets/posters


# Deployment

To deploy API changes to the Lely server you'll have to add the server as a remote to the git repository. Because it's not possible to access the server directly you'll have to use the SSH tunnel. Details to setup this SSH tunnel are in an e-mail with the subject _SSH in to Lely Server_. If you're using Sourcetree to manage this reposity you can follow the next steps to add the server as a remote:

- Make sure you're managing the Lely repository
- Choose _Add remote..._ from _Repository_ in the menu bar
- Give the remote a name (i.e. _Lely Server_)
- Use address of the SSH tunnel for the _URL / path_ field; i.e. _ssh://lust@server.lustlab.net:8084/home/lust/git/lelyapi.git_
- Click _OK_

- Set up tunnel
	- verify if tunnel exists: ssh -p 8084 lust@server.lustlab.net
	- doens't work? Make tunnel on Lely machine. Log in with Logmein and open terminal (cmd) in Windows when logged in.
	- in ~ run ./maketunnels.sh
	- fill in root password of stedelijk.lustlab.net machine. (Digital ocean machine)
	- password is someones last name
	- On your own machine make a ssh connection (see step 1) 
	- Verify connection: http://stedelijk.lustlab.net:8080
	- Tunnel is set up
	
With the remote in place and a tunnel set up to the lely server you can push the repository directly to the server. Users of Sourcetree should follow the next steps:

- Commit your changes and __MAKE SURE YOU DON'T COMMIT _settings.php_!__
- Pull all changes from the Bitbucket repository. __Make sure you select the correct repository in _Pull from repository___)
- Be sure to test the API after pulling and make sure everything still works. There is a python tool in ./api_checker.py to do a crude test of the API. Use python to run this script (_python ./api_checker.py_). __Make sure the _hostname_ variable around line 11 is set to the hostname you use for development and all the available routes are in the _urls_ variable!__ Every route should be successful before deployment!
- Click the _Push_ icon in Sourcetree.
- Choose the right repository (i.e. Lely Server) in the dropdown menu and make sure the _master_ branch is selected.
- Press _OK_ and wait until your changes have been pushed.
- SSH into the server and make sure the changes are in place. (Open a file you know that's been changed or curl to a new route you implemented...)
- To flush memcached execute the following command: _echo 'flush_all' | nc localhost 11211_ This clears the cache of the Lely server and makes all your changes visible.

readme:
# Rietveld

https://rietveldacademie.nl/apply

Local Server Name: rietveld

To Deploy:

Upload to server
Development and Live settings are determined by PHP's HTTP_HOST variable in index.html

---

# reset before next application round starts

nanette (apply@rietveldacademie.nl) usually gets in touch to ask if we can reset the system. that means:
- remove all applicants
- remove all applications
- but keep the users intact

to do that:
- backup the following tables (or just the entire database), then empty them
	- `cms_applicants`
	- `cms_applications`
	- `cms_application_admincomments`
	- `cms_application_comments`
	- `cms_application_media`
	- `cms_application_media_index`
- backup the following directories (rename), then empty them (create new, empty dirs)
	- `/www/media/application_media`
	- `/www/media/uploads`

---

# db migrations

codeigniter has a migrations feature, but for some reason we decided to simply run the migrations manually. see files in `./application/migrations`.

readme:
# LUST Wiki

This project is based [Dillinger.io](http://www.dillinger.io) to provide an easy way to share notes about best practices we should follow in our daily practice. For development this project uses a [Yeoman](http://yeoman.io/) [marionette generator](https://github.com/mrichard/generator-marionette) that depends on (among others):

- NodeJS
- MongoDB
- Express
- Grunt
- Bower
- Backbone Marionette

To setup this Yeoman based development with MongoDB environment you'll have to run:

	brew install node
	brew install mongodb
	npm install -g yo grunt-cli bower generator-marionette

Initialize this project after you've checked out this repository by running inside the repository's directory:
	
	npm install && bower install

To run this project startup MongoDB
	
	mongod

and run grunt
	
	grunt

A new browser tab should open with the location [http://localhost:9000/](http://localhost:9000/)

###DISCLAIMER: This project is still under heavy construction!

name: Generator-Lust
readme:
generator-marionette
======================

Yeoman generator for Express, Marionette and Backbone with AMD

Stack
-------
- Server: 
    * Node: http://nodejs.org/
    * Express: http://expressjs.com/
    * Socket IO: http://socket.io/
- DB: Mongo: http://www.mongodb.org/
- ODM: Mongoose: http://mongoosejs.com
- Client: 
    * Backbone: http://backbonejs.org/
    * Marionette: https://github.com/marionettejs/backbone.marionette
    * jQuery: http://jquery.com/
    * Require: http://requirejs.org/
    * Handlebars: 
        - http://handlebarsjs.com/
        - https://github.com/SlexAxton/require-handlebars-plugin
    * SASS-Bootstrap:
        - http://twitter.github.io/bootstrap
        - https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass
- Tooling: 
    * Yeoman: http://yeoman.io/
    * Bower: http://bower.io/
    * Grunt: http://gruntjs.com/
- Testing:
    * phantomJS http://phantomjs.org/
    * Mocha http://visionmedia.github.io/mocha/
    * Chai http://chaijs.com/
    * Sinon http://sinonjs.org/


Directory structure
-------
- app/                                --> client side files
    * /bower_components               --> bower installs
    * /images
    * /scripts
        - /vendor                     --> 3rd party scripts
        - /models
        - /collections
        - /controllers
        - /routers
        - /regions
        - /views
            * /item
            * /collection
            * /composite
            * /layout
        - init.js                     --> require configuration
        - main.js                     --> application starting point
        - application.js              --> application file

    * /styles                         --> scss files
    * /templates                      --> handlebar templates

- server/                             --> node server files
- test/                               --> unittesting
    * /spec                           --> individual spec files


Install
-------
First make sure you have MongoDB, Node, Npm, Yeoman, Bower and Grunt installed.

Install mongoDB with: 

    $ brew install mongodb 

Or visit http://www.mongodb.org/

Visit nodejs.org to install node and NPM


Install phantomJS with:

    $ brew install phantomjs

Or visit http://phantomjs.org/


To install Yeoman, Bower and Grunt run: 

    $ npm install -g yo grunt-cli bower


Install mocha-phantomjs:

    $ npm install -g mocha-phantomjs


Install mocha generator: 

    $ npm install (-g) generator-mocha-amd


Install marionette generator

    $ npm install (-g) generator-marionette



Bootstrap project
-----------------
To bootstrap a new project simply run:

    $ yo marionette

You have option to include the full express server OR just the marionette generators with a minimal server to develop and run test. No SASS/CSS in the latter. 


To start the app run:

    $ grunt


Unit testing generation
-----------------
The biggest change in this release is the automatic unit test generation as part of the marionette-generator. The Marionette generator calls upon the mocha-amd generator. The default grunt task will automatically run all unit test files via phantom JS. You can also use the browser at localhost:1234/test. Test file generation looks something like the following:

- yo marionette:collection sizes --model size --create-all     // run collection generator
- create app/scripts/collections/sizes.js                       
- invoke   marionette:model
- create     app/scripts/models/size.js
- invoke       mocha-amd:unitTest
- create         test/spec/models/size.js               // unit test for size model
- force         test/spec/testSuite.js
- invoke   mocha-amd:unitTest
- create     test/spec/collections/sizes.js             // unit test for sizes collection
- force     test/spec/testSuite.js                  // testSuite file which lists all test to run



Recommends
-----------------
The generator is most useful using the --creat-all flag. In the example:

    $ yo marionette:compositeview peopleview --itemview personview --create-all

You will get the following files:
   * create **app/scripts/views/composite/people.js**
   * invoke marionette:itemview
   * create **app/scripts/views/item/person.js**
   * invoke marionette:tmpl
   * create **app/templates/item/person_tmpl.hbs**
   * invoke marionette:tmpl
   * create **app/templates/composite/people_tmpl.hbs**


Create routers
--------------
You can generate routers too with

    $ yo marionette:router router-name



Create model
------------
To add a Backbone model to the project use the model generator like this

    $ yo marionette:model model-name

Or to inherit from an existing model

    $ yo marionette:model model-name --inherit model-name



Create collection
-----------------
To add a Backbone collection to the project use collection generator

    $ yo marionette:collection collection-name

You can link the collection with an existent model

    $ yo marionette:collection collection-name model-name

Or may be you want to create both, model and collection on one step

    $ yo marionette:collection collection-name --model model-name --create-all

Or you may want to inherit from another collection

    $ yo marionette:collection collection-name --model model-name --inherit collection-name --create-all




Create views
------------
Backbone works with view definitions, to create one use this command. It is recommended to use Marionette views instead of the standard Backbone view

    $ yo marionette:view view-name




Create item views
------------
Create a Marionette ItemView and link to an existing template at location templates/[template-location]

    $ yo marionette:itemview view-name 

You may want to inherit from another itemview

    $ yo marionette:itemview view-name --inherit view-name

Or maybe you want to create both, itemView and template on one step

    $ yo marionette:itemview view-name --create-all



Create collection views
------------
Create a Marionette CollectionView that is associated to an existing itemview

    $ yo marionette:collectionview view-name --itemview itemview-name

Or inherit from another collectionview

    $ yo marionette:collectionview view-name --itemview itemview-name --inherit view-name

Or maybe you want to create both, itemview (with template) and collectionview.

    $ yo  marionette:collectionview view-name --itemview itemview-name --create-all




Create composite views
------------
Create a Marionette CompositeView

    $ yo marionette:compositeview view-name --itemview itemview-name

Or inherit from another CompositeView

    $ yo marionette:compositeview view-name --itemview itemview-name --inherit view-name

Or maybe you want to create all, itemview and compositeview and both templates. 

    $ yo marionette:compositeview view-name --itemview itemview-name --create-all




Create regions
------------
Create a Marionette Region

    $ yo marionette:region region-name

Or inherit from another Region

    $ yo marionette:region region-name --inherit region-name




Create layouts
------------
Create a Marionette Layout and link to an existing template at location templates/[template-location]

    $ yo marionette:layout layout-name

Or inherit from another layout

    $ yo marionette:layout layout-name --inherit layout-name

Or maybe you want to create both, Layout and template on one step

    $ yo marionette:layout layout-name --create-all



Create controller
------------
Create a Marionette Controller

    $ yo marionette:controller controller-name

Or inherit from another Controller

    $ yo marionette:controller controller-name --inherit controller-name


Create templates
------------
Create a handle bars tmpl

    $ yo marionette:tmpl tmpl-name --tmplLocation tmpl-location

name: IFC
readme:
# IFC

Local Server Name: ifc.localhost

To Install:

npm install
bower install
gulp

To Deploy:

Delete the build directory
Run 'gulp deploy'
Copy index.html and the build directory to the server.

This repository is the main site
There are two others: 
	ifc-atlas
	ifc-megacities

These are for the exhibition.
To deploy these:

Delete the directories 'src' and 'build'
Copy the 'src' directory from this repo to the others.
In atlas and megacities edit the file:
	src/javascript/settings.js
Comment out the variables under DEFAULT and Un-Comment the ATLAS or MEGACITIES block
Run 'gulp deploy'
Copy index.html and the build directory to the 'atlas' or 'megacities' directory on the server

readme:
# WTHX Stream
A platform for live digital communication in a timeline format.

## Usage
To start the server from the `dist` directory, simply run `grunt` from the repository root.

To start the server from the `src` directory during development, run `grunt src` from the repository root.

To compile the application from the `src` directory into the `dist` directory, run `grunt compile`.

## Known issues
### Touch devices
Working on it.

### Crash if no themes found
Make sure you have a collection `themes` with at least one document:
```
#!javascript

{
	_id: some_random_id,
	color: 'ff0000',
	name: 'Some theme'
}
```
description: Version 2 of the WTHX streaming platform

name: WTTC Data 2
readme:
# WTTC Data
 This is a cms (backend) for wttc-datatool. 


# Notes
* it is completely separated from the frontend (frontend has its own api to access to the database)

# Local
* Create a virtual host named `wttc-admin.localhost`.
* development: upadte `src/app/config/config.env.php` with your database details.

#build
* Run `bower install` from the `src` directory.
* Run `composer install` or `php composer.phar install` from the `src` directory.


#deployment
* build on server
* update `src/app/config/config.prod.php` with your database details.
* rename conf file to `config.env.php`
* update `AuthUserFile` in `src/public/.htaccess` file to absolute path of root.
* generate and add a `.htpasswd` file to the root directory.


## Possible queries

- all data for all countries in all years
- all data of type x for all countries in all years
- all data for country x in all years
- all data for all countries in year x
- all data of type x for country y in all years
- all data of type x for all countries in year y
- all data for country x in year y
- all data of type x for country y in year z

name: wttc-dataviz

# WTTC Data Visualisation

Sketches and more

## Data errors

name: wttc-datatool
readme:
# WTTC Data tool

## Requirements

PHP, Apache with Virtual Hosts, MySQL, Memcached server and Memcached PHP extension.

## Notes

* Create a virtual host named `wttc-datatool.local`.
* Copy `src/config/config.template.php` to `src/config/config.php` and fill in your database details.
* Run `bower install` from the `src` directory.


## Possible issues 
* Since the application uses memchased, in case of importing new database you need to free up memchashed!  

## API usage

Send a `POST` request to `http://wttc-datatool.local/api/` with a `payload` parameter that contains a valid JSON string. For example:

```
payload={
	"countries": [
		"NETH",
		"FRANCE"
	],
	"years": {
		"from": 1995,
		"to": 2001
	},
	"metrics": ["pop"]
}
```

name: greyhat-platform
readme:
# readme

> Keystone applies different settings in production and development modes. The environment will default to `development`, so you should set the `NODE_ENV` environment variable to `production` on your production servers for better performance.

[greyhat.lustlab.net](http://greyhat.lustlab.net)

---


# run

```shell
mongod
nodemon [--ext 'js'] keystone.js
open http://localhost:XXXX/
```

# updating keystone

```shell
npm install --save keystone
```

# helpers (to be used in templates)
- keystone exposes [`locals.utils`](https://github.com/keystonejs/keystone-utils).
	- I made some custom `locals.helpers`.
- db field helpers can be accessed via `_.<fieldname>.<helper>` `td #{thread._.createdAt.format('YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ss')}`. for instance [`format()`](https://github.com/keystonejs/keystone/blob/master/lib/fieldTypes/date.js#L44).
	- [explanation](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/keystonejs/underscore/keystonejs/_BUpUPSrx-o/-keNmxRUB-sJ)

---

# DEPLOYMENT

[in order for `bower install` to work](http://stackoverflow.com/a/21790275/2839801) on the lustlab server, I had to do

```shell
git config --global url."https://".insteadOf git://
git config --list
bower install
```

in order to change it back, do `git config --global --unset url."https://".insteadOf`.

__apache site config:__
```xml
<VirtualHost *:80>
	ServerAdmin webmaster@localhost
	ServerName greyhat.lustlab.net
	ServerAlias greyhat.lustlab.net

	DocumentRoot /var/www/sites/greyhat
	<Directory />
		Options FollowSymLinks
		AllowOverride All
	</Directory>

	ProxyRequests on
	ProxyPass / http://localhost:3000/
</VirtualHost>
```

---

# CONFIG

on server (production):

```
NODE_ENV=production
PORT=3000
MANDRILL_API_KEY={KEY}
MANDRILL_USERNAME={NAME}
```

during development:

```
MANDRILL_API_KEY={KEY}
MANDRILL_USERNAME={NAME}
```

---

# notes

commands:

```
# run locally:
nodemon keystone.js

# on the server:
pm2 start --name "greyhat" keystone.js
pm2 restart greyhat
pm2 ls
pm2 stop all

# to start pm2 processes on boot:
# http://pm2.keymetrics.io/docs/usage/startup/
pm2 startup
pm2 save

mongodump --db greyhat -o ~/projects/greyhat/platform/dbdump
mongo greyhat --eval "db.dropDatabase();"
mongorestore --db greyhat .
```

name: gulp-collection-of-sketches
readme:
# what is it?

gulp setup for collections of sketches that share common {css, js, jade} files. 

---

# install

```shell
npm i -g bower
npm i -g browser-sync
npm i
bower init
```

---

# run

the [`gulpfile.js`](./gulpfile.js) dynamically creates tasks for all sub-directories.

```
├── _shared # all shared files
│   ├── css # sass ouput
│   ├── jade
│   │   └── partial.jade
│   ├── js
│   │   └── shared.js
│   └── sass
│       └── site.sass
├── gulpfile.js
[...]
├── sketch-subdir
│   └── src # all source files
│       ├── index.jade
│       ├── js
│       │   └── index.js
│       └── sass
│           └── main.sass
│   ├── build # output dir for `default` task
│   ├── dist # output dir for `dist` task
```

the default task – `gulp` – watches everything for changes, re-compiles, and refreshes the browser. the browser-synced proxy runs on `http://localhost:3000` by default.

individual subdirs can be built for distribution with `gulp --dist <sub-dir-name>`. all the sketch files (including shared files) are compiled and copied to the `dist` directory. that way you can *freeze* a sketch with all its dependencies.

directory names are configurable in the [`gulpfile.js`](./gulpfile.js).

after adding a new subdir, restart `gulp`.

name: pages-watch-dir
readme:
# pages-watch-dir

- `watch.js` (can be used as a replacement of owncloud file change trigger)
	- watches a directory for filesystem events
	- calls webhook
- `server.js`
	- listens for webhook
		- waits for inactivity, before commiting all changes (per subdirectory)
	- serves the frontend


# install

```
git clone https://frederic_lust@bitbucket.org/lustlab/pages-watch-dir.git
cd pages-watch-dir
npm install
```

create `archive` directory and init git repo:

```
mkdir archive
cd archive
git init
git commit --allow-empty -m "init"
cd ..
```


# run

```
# locally
node[mon] server.js

# on server
pm2 start --name 'pages-watch-dir' server.js
```


# configuration

`.env` file:

```
DEBUG=watch,files,git,webhook,db,conversion
INACTIVITY_TIMEOUT=10000
ARCHIVE_PATH=./archive
OWNCLOUD_SYNC_SCRIPT=../sync-archive.sh
ENVIRONMENT=development
DB_NAME=pages-archive
PORT=3099
```


# frontend

is a [react](https://facebook.github.io/react/) / [redux](https://github.com/rackt/redux) app, by default at [http://localhost:3099](http://localhost:3099).

during development run `gulp serve` to watch / compile everything.

# WTHX Interactive ## Installation To start, run `npm install`, which will automatically install dependencies, package the source into the distribution folder, and start the server. ## Socket events | event | description | |-------|-------------| | newpost | fires when a new post has been added, contains the post in JSON format | | newteams | fires when new teams have been generated, contains the new teams in JSON format | | filter | fires when a new filter combination is activated, contains the selected filters | | view | fires when a new view has been selected, contains the selected view | | updatedteam | fires when team has been updated, contains the team information | ## REST API | endpoint | method | description | parameters | |-------------------|--------|----------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | /api/upload | POST | upload new images | `image` _(required)_ the image file | | /api/posts | POST | make a new post | `image` image url
`caption` image caption
`timestamp`
`table` table name
`round` round number
`tags` array of tags | | /api/posts | GET | get all posts | | | /api/posts/:query | GET | search for posts | `query` _(required)_ query in the format of `table=Alpha&round=2` | | /api/posts/:id | PUT | update posts | `id` _(required)_ id of the post
`image` image url
`caption` image caption
`timestamp`
`table` table name
`round` round number
`tags` array of tags | | /api/posts/:id | DELETE | delete a post | `id` _(required)_ id of the post | | /api/teams | POST | generate new teams | `round` _(required)_ round number | | /api/teams | GET | get all teams (past and current) | | | /api/teams/:query | GET | search for teams | `query` _(required)_ query in the format of `table=Alpha&round=2` | | /api/view | POST | change the view | `view` _(required)_ new view | | /api/filter | POST | change the filters | `filters` _(required)_ the filters to apply |

name: net.loadbang.osc
readme:
# `net.loadbang.osc` [![Build Status](https://secure.travis-ci.org/cassiel/net.loadbang.osc.png)](http://travis-ci.org/cassiel/net.loadbang.osc) [![Dependency Status](https://www.versioneye.com/user/projects/52e4ddccec1375b57600002a/badge.png)](https://www.versioneye.com/user/projects/52e4ddccec1375b57600002a)

This is a simple [OSC][osc] library used by our [MaxMSP][max] packages,
and elsewhere (such as directly from Clojure). It is missing some
features (specifically, wildcard matching of paths, and timestamping),
but it does implement OSC-over-TCP as well as the more usual
OSC-over-UDP.

For a Clojure-friendly wrapper to this package, see the lower-level parts of
[`monome-fu`](https://github.com/cassiel/monome-fu).

`net.loadbang.osc` and its dependencies are available in the central Maven repo:

- leiningen:

        [net.loadbang/net.loadbang.osc "1.6.1"]

- maven:

        <dependency>
          <groupId>net.loadbang</groupId>
          <artifactId>net.loadbang.osc</artifactId>
          <version>1.6.1</version>
        </dependency>

## Documentation

The JavaDocs can be generated from Maven by

        mvn javadoc:javadoc

The documentation is written to `target/site/apidocs`.

## License

Distributed under the [GNU General Public License][gpl].

Copyright (C) 2013 Nick Rothwell.

[max]: http://cycling74.com/products/max/
[lib]: https://github.com/cassiel/net.loadbang.lib
[osc]: http://opensoundcontrol.org/
[gpl]: http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/gpl.html
description: Jakobs fork of a quite alright osc library

name: Climap
description: Understanding the existing climate regime is critical to ensuring its ongo- ing viability into the future, which is why ‘mapping’ the convention in all its complexity is so important. But achieving a common understanding is of little value if it does not translate into action. Consequently, the project focuses on enabling all stakeholders to design the regime, and thereby participate mean- ingfully in the discussions around what the regime should like going into the next commitment period. The research phases are designed deliberately to engage stakeholders in a process of critical reflection on the strengths and weaknesses of the current regime, and how to improve it into the future.

name: zandvliet-cms
readme:
#Zandvliet Ledwall CMS

This project lives in a virtual machine running [Homestead](http://laravel.com/docs/5.1/homestead) managed by Vagrant. To run to project you first need to install Vagrant. See [their docs](http://docs.vagrantup.com/v2/getting-started/) for details.

Once Vagrant is install you can run _vagrant up_ to start the virtual machine. And yes, this takes a while... Then add this line to your hosts file:

    192.168.10.10  zandvliet.dev

When vagrant is done installing the virtual machine ssh into the machine by using the command _vagrant ssh_ and navigate to _/home/vagrant/vm/cms_ and run:
	
	sudo composer install
	npm install

After this navigate to _/home/vagrant/vm/cms/resources_ and run:

	bower install

The next step is to setup the database. To do this navigate back to _/home/vagrant/vm/cms_ and run the following commands:

	php artisan migrate
	php artisan db:seed
	php artisan key:generate

Now you're ready to start developing. To do this navigate back to _/home/vagrant/vm/cms_ and run _gulp copy_ to copy some Bower components and other resources to the public folder. The final step is to run _gulp watch_ to update the project while you're making changes.

name: AbletonVeghel
readme:
Installation Procedure Sound Veghel

-- essential

1. Install Ableton Live incl. Max for Live
2. Copy folder LiveOSC/ in "Midi Remote Scripts"-folder
	(probably \ProgramData\Ableton\Live 9.2.2\Resources\MIDI Remote Scripts\ )
	see also https://www.ableton.com/en/help/article/install-third-party-remote-script/

-- testing ableton setup

1. install pyOSC as described in pyosc/
2. run python/vegheltools.py -h to see available options


Trouble shooting:
?: Live does not react to OSC input
-> The port might be clogged. close Ableton Live and run "python python/portKill.py -k 9009".
   This happens for example if you open Max for Live during a session to edit a midi effect.

name: hubbub-backend
readme:
# Hubbub API

## What it should do
The project should provide the backend for the [Hubbub CoR app](https://corapp.org). This means it’s able to:
- Register users
- Send notifications to users
- Store the data/sounds that users submit
- Analyse the sound files.

## Stack
- Using [Express](http://expressjs.com/) as the Node.JS web framework.
- MySQL database in combination with [Knex](http://knexjs.org/).
- Sound analysis is being done using the Python bindings for [Essentia](essentia.upf.edu).
- [Agenda](https://github.com/rschmukler/agenda) for job scheduling.
- [Webpack](https://webpack.github.io/) as our module bundler.
- ES6 support via [babel](https://babeljs.io) with [async/await](https://zeit.co/blog/async-and-await) functionality.

## Getting Started
- First of all, make sure you have NodeJS/NPM (v4.x / v2.x) and a MySQL server (v5.6.x) installed.
- Install Essential and it’s Python bindings.
- Install FFMpeg.
- Make sure you have Knex installed globally (for using the migrations). [Read the docs for this](http://knexjs.org/#Migrations).
- Create a new database for this project.
- Create a _.env_ file. Look at the _.env.example_ for what should be in there.
- Run the Knex migrations by running `knex migrate:latest` in the root of your project.
- Install all dependencies with `npm install`
- Make sure you have [nodemon](https://github.com/remy/nodemon) installed globally to watch for changes and restart your server if necessary.
- Run the job scheduler with `node server/worker.js`
- Start the server with	`npm start`

## Development
Development should be pretty straight forward.
- All the Python and bash code for sound analysis is in the _analysis_ folder.
- All the server side code for the API is in the _server_ directory.
- When you need to make changes to the database you should create a migration using Knex. See their [docs](http://knexjs.org/#Migrations) on how to do that.

## Testing
Some pretty simple (acceptence) tests have been implemented to test incoming API requests and check their response. The tests are located in `/tests`. To run the tests you run the command `npm run test`.

## Deployment
Since we’re using Babel we first need to transpile our ES6/ES7 code to ES5. We can do all of this (and more) using the package script.
- Run `./package.sh` inside the root of your project to create a _dist_ folder.
- Upload the contents of this folder to _/var/www/backend_ on the server (_cor.lustlab.net_)
- To restart the server you have to run
	- `pm2 restart server`
	- `pm2 restart worker`

## Debugging
If you want to view to server logs you can run `pm2 logs server` or `pm2 logs worker` on the server. Agenda (the job scheduler) also has a UI in case you want to have an overview of what jobs are going on. You can start this UI by running `pm2 start agendash`. This will make _https://cor.lustlab.net/agenda/_ show an overview of the jobs. Make sure to stop agendash when you’re done debugging with `pm2 stop agendash`.

- [hacksplaining.com](https://www.hacksplaining.com/)

---


## Server setup

- [Initial setup](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/initial-server-setup-with-ubuntu-16-04)
	+ Use SSH keys instead of passwords to login to server
	+ Don't use root user
	+ Create secure passwords
	+ [Only open ports you actually need](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/ufw-essentials-common-firewall-rules-and-commands), probably:
		* 22: ssh
		* 80: http
		* 443: https
- [How To Install Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP ](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-install-linux-apache-mysql-php-lamp-stack-on-ubuntu-14-04)
- Apache
	+ Are there tools to check for security mistakes?
	+ Directory listing should be off by default
	+ .git directory should not be public
	+ You should try to install SSL certificates ([guide](./ssl-certificate.md))
- Databases
	+ Mysql
		* Don't use root user
		* use SequelPro (or command line) + SSH access to access mysql
		* Don't install PhpMyAdmin (or Wordpress) EVER
	+ Should only allow access from localhost
	+ What about MongoDb?


## Git

- [remove sensitive data](https://help.github.com/articles/remove-sensitive-data/)
- Deployment w/ git
	+ Only when you don't need to compile source (so don't use it when you're using webpack / gulp / whatever)
	+ [Use deployment keys](https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/use-deployment-keys-294486051.html)
	+ Don't make changes to your source on the server. You shouldn't be able to commit it anyways since you're using the (read-only) deployment key (right?).
	+ Hide your .git directory, preferably don't put it in a public folder. You should probably make a public folder inside your git project to link Apache to:
		* /var/www/project/.git
		* /var/www/project/public/index.html


## HTTPS

- [SSL Certificates](./ssl-certificate.md)


## Web stuff

- CORS
	+ Use ReverseProxy to fix CORS problems... i.e. you want to request localhost:3000/api from localhost you can add the following line to your Apache config:

	`ProxyPass /api http://localhost:3000`

	Now you can make requests to localhost/api that will be proxied to localhost:3000.

- HTML forms CSRF tokens
	+ We didn't discuss this. Not sure if this is really important
- Authentication
	+ JWT (Json Web Tokens)
		* You'll send these as headers to endpoints that are protected and are meant to validate a (authenticated) user. See [jwt.io](https://jwt.io)) for more information and implementations.
	+ Store passwords w/ bcrypt (because reasons)


## Project

- Passwords / Api keys / et cetera in your project
	+ Shouln't go in Git. Obviously
		* In case you did: https://help.github.com/articles/remove-sensitive-data/
	+ write a .env.example / .config.example template file for passwords / keys / settings.

readme:
### What is this repository for? ###

this repo exists to document and keep track of issues relating to the server-migration process



### How do I get set up? ###

Login:
`ssh serveradmin@lust.nl@lust.nl`

Projects are located at `/home/38758/users/.home/domains/`


#### Use rsync
Customize the following script to copy a remote folder to a local one or vice versa.

`excludes.txt` should contain a list of directory or file names that should not be copied.


Using the `--dry-run` option will only show the output of the program, but will not make any changes. Disable this when running the script `FOR REAL™`.

save this script to a file eg. `sync.sh`, do `chmod +x sync.sh` (make it executable), run it `./sync.sh`

```
#!/usr/bin/env bash

SOURCE="serveradmin@lust.nl@lust.nl:/home/38758/users/.home/domains/"
TARGET='./archive'
EXCLUDE='./excludes.txt'

function sync(){
    BLUE='\033[0;34m'
    NC='\033[0m'
    echo -e "${BLUE}rsyncing ${1} -> ${2}${NC}"
    rsync --exclude-from=${EXCLUDE} --archive --dry-run --compress --delete --ignore-existing  --verbose --partial --progress $1 $2
}


mkdir -p ${TARGET}
sync  ${SOURCE} ${TARGET}
```

# MAKE SURE YOUR LOCAL COPY OF THE PROJECTS IS NOT CHECKED INTO THIS REPO



### Useful commands ###

show folders and their size in cwd sorted by size
```
du -hsx * | sort -rh
```





### Who do I talk to? ###

* Amir & Gabor

name: indexer
readme:
# Indexer
Indexer is an application that generates document maps and annotates articles.

Indexer maintains its persistent state using MapDB 3.0.x, its data is stored in indexer.mapdb

## Running Indexer

Indexer is packaged in a single jar distribution. Running it requires the Java 8 runtime to be installed.

```
java -jar indexer.jar server indexer.yaml
```

## Running Indexer on CDA

Same as the normal setup. Edit the `indexer-cda.yaml` file to set the masterUrl correctly, it should point to the indexer running on the CMS

```
java -jar indexer.jar server indexer-cda.yaml
```

## Running Indexer as a service

--to be written--

# API
 
Indexer comes with a simple REST-ish API.
The API is intended to be used from within a facading application, proxying or otherwise exposing the API to the world is not advisory.

## End-point Index

```
GET     /map                -- returns all the data needed to draw the map
GET     /map/build-map      -- rebuilds the map
GET     /search/{id-or-slug}        -- retrieves most relevant artciles for article with {id-or-slug}

POST    /articles           -- add a new article
DELETE  /articles/{id}      -- remove an article
PUT     /articles/{id}      -- update an article
GET     /articles/{id}      -- retrieves an article

GET     /entities           -- lists all entities
POST    /entities           -- adds a new entity
PUT     /entities/{id}      -- updates an entity
DELETE  /entities/{id}      -- deletes an entity

```

## Map

```
GET /map
```


## Search

The search API provides functionality to search for semantically relevant articles.

To search for relevant articles one requests:
```
GET http://<host>/search/id/{id}
GET http://<host>/search/slug/{slug}
```

Optionally one can add requests argument `?count={count}` to control the number of articles in the response, the default count is set to 5.

The response is a JSON encoded object
```!javascript 
Response = [
    {
        id: <[UUID as string]>      // internal use 
        originalId: <string>        // the id as used in the AUFI database
        slug: <string>              // slug as used in AUFI database
        title: <string>             // title of the article
        x: <number>                 // the x position in the article map
        y: <number>                 // the y position in the article map
    }
]
```

 
## Entities

Entities are used to annotate articles. Indexer stores entities.

#### Entity model

```!javascript
Entity {
    id: <UUID as string>
    parent: <UUID as string | null>     // optional
    name: <string>,
    nameCI: <string | null>,            // optional; filled in by back-end
    synonyms: <[string] | []>,          // optional
    string type: <string | null>        // optional
    string subtype: <string | null>     // optional
    stemmed: <boolean>
    caseSensitive: <boolean>        
}
```

#### Listing entities

To get a a full list of entities one requests
```
GET http://<host>/entities
```

The response is a JSON encoded list of `Entity` objects 

#### Adding an entity
To add an entity to the entity-base one posts a JSON encoded `entity` object to the API
```
POST http://<host>/entities
```

The response will be a JSON encoded object with the `id` field set. The request will fail when the id is set or when the supplied JSON is malformed.

#### Updating an entity

To update an entity one posts a JSON encoded `entity` object to the API

```
PUT http://<host>/entities/{id}
```

The request will fail when the entity identified by `id` does not exist, when the path `id` does not match the object `id`, or when the supplied JSON is malformed 

#### Deleting an entity

Deleting an `entity` identified by `id` is performed by sending the request: 

```
DELETE http://<host>/entities/{id}
```

The request will fail when there is no entity for the given `id` is found.


## Articles

After adding or deleting an article the `/map/build-map` end-point needs to be called

#### Article Model 
```javascript
Article {
    uuid: <UUID as string>,
    subtitle: String,
    theme: String,  
    id: String,             // -- the article id in the AUFI database
    text: String
    slug: String            // -- the slug in the AUFI database
    publicationDate: Date   // -- unix timestamp    
}
```

#### Adding an article

```
POST http://<host>/articles
```

#### Deleting an article


```
DELETE http://<host>/articles
```

name: pages-syncthing
readme:
istepanov/syncthing
===================

[![Docker Stars](https://img.shields.io/docker/stars/istepanov/syncthing.svg)](https://hub.docker.com/r/istepanov/syncthing/)
[![Docker Pulls](https://img.shields.io/docker/pulls/istepanov/syncthing.svg)](https://hub.docker.com/r/istepanov/syncthing/)
[![Docker Build](https://img.shields.io/docker/automated/istepanov/syncthing.svg)](https://hub.docker.com/r/istepanov/syncthing/)
[![Layers](https://images.microbadger.com/badges/image/istepanov/syncthing.svg)](https://microbadger.com/images/istepanov/syncthing)
[![Version](https://images.microbadger.com/badges/version/istepanov/syncthing.svg)](https://microbadger.com/images/istepanov/syncthing)
[![Join the chat at https://gitter.im/istepanov/docker-syncthing](https://badges.gitter.im/Join%20Chat.svg)](https://gitter.im/istepanov/docker-syncthing?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&utm_content=badge)

[Syncthing](http://syncthing.net/) Docker image

### How to run

Simpliest way to run this container is by using [docker-compose.yml](docker-compose.yml) file. Simply run:

    wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/istepanov/docker-syncthing/master/docker-compose.yml
    docker-compose up -d

Then access Syncthing Web UI at [http://localhost:8384/]().

To update the container, run:

    docker-compose pull
    docker-compose up -d

You can also start the container manually without using Docker Compose:

    # Container requires 2 volumes: for config and for data.
    CONFIG_VOLUME='syncthing-config'
    DATA_VOLUME='syncthing-data'
    CONTAINER_NAME='syncthing'

    docker run -d \
        --name $CONTAINER_NAME \
        --restart always \
        -p 8384:8384 -p 22000:22000 -p 21027:21027/udp \
        -v $CONFIG_VOLUME:/home/syncthing/.config/syncthing \
        -v $DATA_VOLUME:/home/syncthing/Sync \
        istepanov/syncthing

_Note_: `--restart always` (or `--restart on-failure` or `--restart unless-stopped`) is required because Syncthing restarts itself during auto-update. Without this option container just stops after first update.

### Enabling HTTPS for Web UI

The image itself tends to be minimal and doesn't provide any HTTPS functionality. If you want to have a SSL connection between your browser and Syncthing Web UI, you need to put a proxy container that will handle HTTPS connections.

The easiest way to do it is by using Let's Encrypt certifcates and 3 additional containers: [official Nginx image](https://hub.docker.com/_/nginx/), [jwilder/docker-gen](https://github.com/jwilder/docker-gen) image to auto-generate Nginx configs and [jrcs/letsencrypt-nginx-proxy-companion](https://github.com/JrCs/docker-letsencrypt-nginx-proxy-companion) image to auto-generate/auto-renew SSL certificates. To orchestrate all containers, we'll use [docker-compose-https.yml](docker-compose-https.yml) file:

    wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/istepanov/docker-syncthing/master/docker-compose-https.yml

    # before launching, we need to prepare 2 docker volumes:
    docker volume create --driver local --name certs
    docker volume create --driver local --name nginx-templates

    # download nginx template into "nginx-templates" volume
    docker run --rm -v nginx-templates:/tmp/nginx-templates alpine /bin/sh -c 'apk add --no-cache curl ca-certificates && curl -o /tmp/nginx-templates/nginx.tmpl https://gist.githubusercontent.com/istepanov/6c19d1e519196e9b74f76344353fe837/raw/fc8784d1cbc8ad56047b10630b68c1830859bf63/nginx.tmpl'

    # Setup env vars that will be used by Docker Compose file.
    # SYNCTHING_HOSTNAME must be accessible from outside, otherwise SSL certificate won't be generated.
    # Make sure port 80 is open and the domain name is resolvable.
    # (this is an example, replace this with real values)
    export SYNCTHING_HOSTNAME='syncthing.myserver.host'
    export LETSENCRYPT_EMAIL='my@email.host'

    docker-compose -f docker-compose-https.yml up -d

Make sure you set `LETSENCRYPT_EMAIL` and `LETSENCRYPT_EMAIL` env vars before running Docker Compose commands. You can also edit `docker-compose-https.yml` and replace these vars with real values.

name: aufi-map
readme:
##setup

you need node and npm installed.

1. clone this repository.
2. run `npm install`


##development


relevant code is in `src/mindmap`.


start webpack dev server:

`npm run dev`

visit localhost:3000. page will reload on file changes in the src folder.
for more information look at webpack/dev.config.js



##build
`npm run build`

this will create a js and css bundle from `src/mindmap` in the `dist` directory.
for more information look at webpack/prod.config.js

the sandbox folder is there to check if the build worked properly. copy the js and css files from dist/ to sandbox/, replace their references in the html file, then `cd sandbox && python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8080`, visit localhost:8080 and see if the map is properly rendered.

##publish

1. create an app password for your bitbucket account with write access to repositories. you can do so at `https://bitbucket.org/account/user/<your-bitbucket-username>/app-passwords`. make note of the password that will pop up. [more info](https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/app-passwords-828781300.html)
2. create a `.env` file at the root of the directory, with the following contents: `export BB_AUTH_STRING=<your-bitbucket-username>:<your-app-password>` for example: `export BB_AUTH_KEY=krks:$uP3r$3Cr3tPa$$w0rD`

3. now you can hopefully run `npm run publish` which will create a build and upload it to the downloads section of the repository.
4. the build should be available now at https://bitbucket.org/LUSTlab/aufi-map/downloads/?tab=downloads as `build.tar.gz`


##usage

the map attaches itself to the window through a `renderMindMap` function that expects a configuration object as an argument.

the map can be drawn in two different modes: default and `context`. the default mode is the one intended to be used on the front page, `context` mode is to be used for the small map next to an article to show neighbouring articles.

###config

####`data` object
object
map data

####`targetNode` DOM node
DOM node render target, eg. document.getElementById('mindMapContainer').
the map will fill up the available space in this node.


####`colorTheme` string
can  either be 'dark' or 'light'

####`onArticleRequested` function
callback that should be run when an article is clicked, receives the article's `slug` as argument


####`onArticleListRequested` function
callback that should be run when a cluster is clicked, receives an array of `slug`s as arg. will not be called in 'context' mode.

	
####`mode` optional, string	
either `'context'` or undefined. if undefined, the map will render in default mode.

####`contextArticleID` string
if 'context' is specified as mode, set this to the id of the article that should be brought to the center of the map


## examples
**normal mode**
```

fetchData().then(mapData => {
	renderMindMap({
	    data: mapData,
	    targetNode: document.getElementById('mindMapContainer'), 
	    colorTheme: 'dark',
	    onArticleRequested: slug => console.log(slug),
	    onArticleListRequested: slugs => slugs.forEach(slug => console.log(slug))
	});
});


```

**context mode**
```

fetchData().then(mapData => {
	renderMindMap({
		data: mapData,
		mode: 'context',
		targetNode: document.getElementById('contextMapContainer'),
		colorTheme: 'light',
		contextArticleSlug: 'some-slug',
		onArticleRequested: slug => console.log(slug),
	});
});

```

Gabor Kerekes

gabor@lustlab.net
